dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to documents filed on Monday afternoon with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the worlds richest man sold over 530,000 shares of Amazon when the stock price was around $1,900 a share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then the stock closed at $3,000 on Monday? So he might've left some money on the table there.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True, but why sell all that? The spokesperson said the funds would go to buy Twitter? That seems... unlikely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but why sell all that? The spokesperson said the funds would go to buy Twitter? That seems... unlikely.

dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that part feels off. The leading theory is actually to fund Virgin Galactic, his space company.

dialogue_turns.text: Virgin Galactic—founded back in 2010, right? He did mention funding it through loans in 2019.

dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Selling shares could be another way to free up cash without taking on more debt.

dialogue_turns.text: Still, mixing up Google and Amazon in the same breath is just sloppy reporting.

artist_script:
HostA: Jeff Bezos, the former CEO of Google? That's a pretty glaring error right there—he founded Amazon, not Google.
HostB: Oh, whoops, you're totally right. But, um, the real story is that $2.4 billion after-tax sale of Tesla stock in early July—that's what caught my eye.
HostA: Wait, but he sold Amazon shares in August, not Tesla. The text says Tesla was back in July. Which is it?
HostB: Yeah, it's a bit, but look—the documents filed with the Federal Trade Commission mention over 350,000 Tesla shares sold at around $2,800 each.
HostA: And then the stock closed at $3,000 on Monday? So he might've left some money on the table there.
HostB: Possibly, but with an estimated net worth of $90.1 billion, I don't think he's sweating it too much.
HostA: True, but why sell all that? The spokesperson said the funds would go to buy Twitter? That seems... unlikely.
HostB: Yeah, that part feels off. The leading theory is actually to fund Virgin Galactic, his space company.
HostA: Virgin Galactic—founded back in 2010, right? He did mention funding it through loans in 2019.
HostB: Exactly. Selling shares could be another way to free up cash without taking on more debt.
HostA: Still, mixing up Google and Amazon in the same breath is just sloppy reporting.
